commander.name: Carlo Gotti
commander.notes: Commanded Bologna Division until succeeded by Alessandro Gloria in August 1941

Ambulances.notes: 66th Surgical Unit, 96th & 528th Field Hospitals, 308th Field Ambulance

100/17 Mod. 14 Howitzer.notes: I Gruppo, 205th Artillery Regiment Bologna (replaced 10th Artillery Regiment)

75/27 Mod. 06 Field Gun.notes: II & III Gruppi, 205th Artillery Regiment Bologna

65/17 Mod. 13.notes: 4 per infantry regiment, support weapons companies

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive siege operations, strained for offensive operations. Primary constraint: fuel and water delivery from Benghazi (800km). Tobruk harbor contested, forcing reliance on overland supply through Bardia. Water supply critical in Cyrenaica coastal desert.

subordinate_units.notes: Arrived North Africa April 1941 as replacement for destroyed 10th Artillery Regiment. Home station: Caserta

tactical_doctrine.role: Siege operations against Tobruk fortress. Advanced from Sirte to Tobruk May 1941 following Axis Operation Sonnenblume. Assigned to eastern sector of Tobruk perimeter, containing British 70th Infantry Division garrison.
special_capabilities: Desert-acclimatized from service in Libya since pre-war
Siege warfare experience against fortified positions
Sustained defensive operations in arid environment
known_issues: Insufficient motor transport for simultaneous full division movement
Weak anti-tank capability (8 x 47mm guns) against British Matilda/Crusader tanks
Minimal anti-aircraft defense vulnerable to British air superiority from Tobruk
Artillery regiment replacement (205th) arrived April 1941, limited integration time
Water supply constraints in Cyrenaica desert operations
Extended supply lines from Tripoli/Benghazi vulnerable to British interdiction
Binary division structure (2 regiments vs 3) reduces combat depth
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Equipped with SPA AS.37 Sahariano desert vehicles. Increased water transport capacity. Light uniforms and sun helmets. Field fortifications adapted for rocky coastal terrain. Experience from Graziani's 1940 advance into Egypt.

wargaming_data.experience_level: Veteran (combat experience from 1940 Egypt advance and 1941 British counteroffensive)
special_rules: Siege Warfare: +1 in prepared siege positions against fortified enemy
Desert Veteran: No penalties for desert operations, heat, or water scarcity
Semi-Motorized: May move at truck speed if corps transport allocated, otherwise foot speed
Supply Dependent: -1 morale if out of supply for more than 2 turns
British Air Superiority: -1 to all combat rolls if British aircraft present
Tobruk Siege Operations: +1 defensive bonus in static positions, -1 for mobile operations
historical_engagements: Graziani advance into Egypt September 1940 (Sidi Barrani)
10th Artillery Regiment destroyed at Ajdabiya February 1941
Operation Sonnenblume advance to Tobruk May 1941
Siege of Tobruk April-December 1941 (ongoing in Q2)
wargaming_data.notable_actions: Division suffered heavily in British Operation Compass (December 1940-February 1941). 10th Artillery Regiment destroyed north of Ajdabiya 5 February 1941. Reconstituted with 205th Artillery Regiment April 1941. Advanced to Tobruk May 1941. Assigned siege operations eastern perimeter, containing British 70th Division garrison. Would repulse British breakout attempt 21 November 1941 during Operation Crusader.

source: Order of Battle of the Italian Army - USA HQ G2 July 1943 (primary source)
TM E 30-420 Handbook on Italian Military Forces August 1943
Comando Supremo: Alessandro Gloria biography (commander succession)
Generals.dk: Carlo Gotti biography (1941 Q2 commander)
Italian binary autotrasportabile division organizational tables
Cross-reference with 17th Pavia Division (similar autotrasportabile structure)
validation.notes: Personnel total 7,650 based on standard Italian binary autotrasportabile infantry division TO&E (TM 30-420). Artillery regiment changed April 1941: 10th Artillery Regiment destroyed at Ajdabiya 5 February 1941, replaced by 205th Artillery Regiment arriving April 1941. Division timeline: Present in Libya pre-war, participated in Graziani's September 1940 Egypt advance (Sidi Barrani), retreated during British Operation Compass (December 1940-February 1941), reconstituted March-April 1941, advanced to Tobruk May 1941 during Operation Sonnenblume. Commander Carlo Gotti confirmed November 1941, assumed to command from early 1941. Succeeded by Alessandro Gloria 25 August 1941 (1941-Q3). Division classified as 'semi-motorized' (autotrasportabile) with organic truck transport but insufficient for simultaneous full division movement. Home stations: divisional HQ Naples, 39th Regiment Caserta, 40th Regiment Naples, 205th Artillery Caserta. Division destroyed at El Alamein November 1942. Personnel and equipment counts reflect May-June 1941 status during Tobruk siege operations.
